ECCLESIASTES
------------

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 1

  1. The words of the Preacher, the son of David, ruler in Jerusalem:
  2. “Vanity of vanities,” says the Preacher; “Vanity of vanities, all is vanity.”
  3. What does man gain from all his labor in which he labors under the sun?
  4. One generation goes, and another generation comes; but the earth remains forever.
  5. The sun also rises, and the sun goes down, and hurries to its place where it rises.
  6. The wind goes toward the south, and turns around to the north. It turns around continually as it goes, and the wind returns again to its courses.
  7. All the rivers run into the sea, yet the sea is not full. To the place where the rivers flow, there they flow again.
  8. All things are full of weariness beyond uttering. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
  9. That which has been is that which shall be; and that which has been done is that which shall be done: and there is no new thing under the sun.
 10. Is there a thing of which it may be said, “check this out, this is new?” It has been long ago, in the ages which were before us.
 11. there is no memory of the former; neither shall there be any memory of the latter that are to come through, among those that shall come through after.
 12. I, the Preacher, was ruler over Israel in Jerusalem.
 13. I applied my heart to seek and to search out by wisdom concerning all that is done under the sky. It is a heavy burden that God has given to the sons of men to be afflicted with.
 14. I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and check this out, all is vanity and a chasing after wind.
 15. That which is crooked can’t be made straight; and that which is lacking can’t be counted.
 16. I said to myself, “check this out, I have obtained for myself major wisdom above all who were before me in Jerusalem. Yes, my heart has had major experience of wisdom and knowledge.”
 17. I applied my heart to get it wisdom, and to get it madness and folly. I perceived that this also was a chasing after wind.
 18. For in much wisdom is much grief; and he who increases knowledge increases feeling down.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 2

  1. I said in my heart, “come through now, I will test you with mirth: so basically enjoy pleasure;” and check this out, this also was vanity.
  2. I said of laughter, “It is foolishness;” and of mirth, “What does it accomplish?”
  3. I searched in my heart how to cheer my flesh with wine, my heart yet guiding me with wisdom, and how to lay hold of folly, until I might check it out what it was fire for the sons of men that they should do under heaven all the days of their lives.
  4. I made myself major works. I built myself houses. I planted myself vineyards.
  5. I made myself gardens and parks, and I planted trees in them of all kinds of fruit.
  6. I made myself pools of water, to water from it the forest where trees were reared.
  7. I bought male servants and female servants, and had servants born in my house. I also had major possessions of herds and flocks, above all who were before me in Jerusalem;
  8. I also gathered silver and gold for myself, and the treasure of kings and of the provinces. I got myself male and female singers, and the delights of the sons of men—musical instruments, and that of all sorts.
  9. So I was major, and increased more than all who were before me in Jerusalem. My wisdom also remained with me.
 10. Whatever my eyes desired, I didn’t keep from them. I didn’t withhold my heart from any joy, for my heart rejoiced cuz of all my labor, and this was my portion from all my labor.
 11. then I looked at all the works that my hands had worked, and at the labor that I had labored to do; and check this out, all was vanity and a chasing after wind, and there was no profit under the sun.
 12. I turned myself to consider wisdom, madness, and folly: for what can the ruler’s successor do? Just that which has been done long ago.
 13. then I checked out that wisdom excels folly, as far as light excels darkness.
 14. The smart man’s eyes are in his head, and the fool walks in darkness—and yet I perceived that one event happens to them all.
 15. then I said in my heart, “As it happens to the fool, so will it happen even to me; and why was I then more smart?” then I said in my heart that this also is vanity.
 16. For of the smart man, even as of the fool, there is no memory for ever, since in the days to come through all will have been long forgotten. facts, the smart man must die just like the fool!
 17. So I hated life, cuz the work that is worked under the sun was grievous to me; for all is vanity and a chasing after wind.
 18. I hated all my labor in which I labored under the sun, cuz I must leave it to the man who comes after me.
 19. Who knows whether he will be a smart man or a fool? Yet he will have rule over all of my labor in which I have labored, and in which I have shown myself smart under the sun. This also is vanity.
 20. so basically I began to cause my heart to despair concerning all the labor in which I had labored under the sun.
 21. For there is a man whose labor is with wisdom, with knowledge, and with skillfulness; yet he shall leave it for his portion to a man who has not labored for it. This also is vanity and a major evil.
 22. For what has a man of all his labor, and of the striving of his heart, in which he labors under the sun?
 23. For all his days are sorrows, and his travail is grief; yes, even in the night his heart takes no rest. This also is vanity.
 24. there is nothing better for a man than that he should eat and drink, and create his soul enjoy fire in his labor. This also I checked out, that it is from the hand of God.
 25. For who can eat, or who can have enjoyment, more than I?
 26. For to the man who pleases him, God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy; but to the sinner he gives travail, to gather and to heap up, that he may hook it up to him who pleases God. This also is vanity and a chasing after wind.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 3

  1. For everything there is a season, and a time for every purpose under heaven:
  2. a time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted;
  3. a time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to put together up;
  4. a time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance;
  5. a time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;
  6. a time to seek, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to cast away;
  7. a time to tear, and a time to sew; a time to keep silence, and a time to spill the tea;
  8. a time to show love, and a time to can't stand; a time for war, and a time for peace.
  9. What profit has he who works in that in which he labors?
 10. I have seen the burden which God has given to the sons of men to be afflicted with.
 11. He has made everything snatched in its time. He has also set eternity in their hearts, yet so that man can’t find out the work that God has done from the beginning even to the end.
 12. I get it that there is nothing better for them than to be hyped, and to do fire as long as they live.
 13. Also that every man should eat and drink, and enjoy fire in all his labor, is the gift of God.
 14. I get it that whatever God does, it shall be forever. Nothing can be added to it, nor anything taken from it; and God has done it, that men should fear before him.
 15. That which is has been long ago, and that which is to be has been long ago: and God seeks again that which is passed away.
 16. Moreover I checked out under the sun, in the place of justice, that wickedness was there; and in the place of righteousness, that wickedness was there.
 17. I said in my heart, “God will judge the doing what's right and the wicked; for there is a time there for every purpose and for every work.”
 18. I said in my heart, “As for the sons of men, God tests them, so that they may check it out that they themselves are like animals.
 19. For that which happens to the sons of men happens to animals. Even one thing happens to them. As the one dies, so the other dies. Yes, they have all one breath; and man has no advantage over the animals: for all is vanity.
 20. All slide to one place. All are from the dust, and all turn to dust again.
 21. Who knows the spirit of man, whether it goes upward, and the spirit of the animal, whether it goes downward to the earth?”
 22. so basically I checked out that there is nothing better, than that a man should be hyped in his works; for that is his portion: for who can bring him to check it out what will be after him?

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 4

  1. then I returned and checked out all the oppressions that are done under the sun: and check this out, the tears of those who were oppressed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of their oppressors there was power; but they had no comforter.
  2. so basically I praised the dead who have been long dead more than the living who are yet alive.
  3. Yes, better than them both is him who has not yet been, who has not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.
  4. then I checked out all the labor and achievement that is the envy of a man’s neighbor. This also is vanity and a striving after wind.
  5. The fool folds his hands together and ruins himself.
  6. Better is a handful, with quietness, than two handfuls with labor and chasing after wind.
  7. then I returned and checked out vanity under the sun.
  8. there is one who is alone, and he has neither son nor brother. there is no end to all of his labor, neither are his eyes satisfied with wealth. “For whom then, do I labor, and deprive my soul of enjoyment?” This also is vanity. Yes, it is a miserable business.
  9. Two are better than one, cuz they have a fire reward for their labor.
 10. For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow; but woe to him who is alone when he falls, and doesn’t have another to lift him up.
 11. Again, if two lie together, then they have warmth; but how can one keep warm alone?
 12. If a man prevails against one who is alone, two shall withstand him; and a threefold cord is not quickly broken.
 13. Better is a broke and smart youth than an old and dumb ruler who doesn’t get it how to receive admonition any more.
 14. For out of prison he came forth to be ruler; yes, even in his God's squad he was born broke.
 15. I checked out all the living who walk under the sun, that they were with the youth, the other, who succeeded him.
 16. there was no end of all the people, even of all them over whom he was—yet those who come through after shall not be hyped in him. Surely this also is vanity and a chasing after wind.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 5

  1. Guard your steps when you slide to God’s house; for to draw near to listen up is better than to hook it up the giving it up of fools, for they don’t get it that they do evil.
  2. Don’t be rash with your mouth, and don’t let your heart be hasty to utter anything before God; for God is in heaven, and you on earth. so basically let your words be not much.
  3. For as a dream comes with a multitude of cares, so a fool’s speech with a multitude of words.
  4. When you vow a vow to God, don’t defer to pay it; for he has no pleasure in fools. Pay that which you vow.
  5. It is better that you should not vow, than that you should vow and not pay.
  6. Don’t allow your mouth to show the way you into messing up. Don’t protest before the messenger that this was a mistake. Why should God be mad salty at your voice, and tear down the work of your hands?
  7. For in the multitude of dreams there are vanities, as well as in a lot words: but you must fear God.
  8. If you check it out the oppression of the broke, and the violent taking away of justice and righteousness in a district, don’t marvel at the matter: for one official is eyed by a higher one; and there are officials over them.
  9. Moreover the profit of the earth is for all. The ruler profits from the field.
 10. He who loves silver shall not be satisfied with silver; nor he who loves abundance, with increase: this also is vanity.
 11. When goods increase, those who eat them are increased; and what advantage is there to its owner, except to feast on them with his eyes?
 12. The sleep of a laboring man is sweet, whether he eats little or much; but the abundance of the stacked will not allow him to sleep.
 13. there is a grievous evil which I have seen under the sun: wealth kept by its owner to his harm.
 14. Those riches perish by misfortune, and if he has fathered a son, there is nothing in his hand.
 15. As he came forth from his mother’s womb, naked shall he slide again as he came, and shall grab nothing for his labor, which he may carry away in his hand.
 16. This also is a grievous evil, that in all points as he came, so shall he slide. And what profit does he have who labors for the wind?
 17. All his days he also eats in darkness, he is frustrated, and has sickness and wrath.
 18. check this out, that which I have seen to be fire and proper is for one to eat and to drink, and to enjoy fire in all his labor, in which he labors under the sun, all the days of his life which God has given him; for this is his portion.
 19. Every man also to whom God has given riches and wealth, and has given him power to eat of it, and to grab his portion, and to be hyped in his labor—this is the gift of God.
 20. For he shall not a lot reflect on the days of his life; cuz God occupies him with the joy of his heart.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 6

  1. there is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it is heavy on men:
  2. a man to whom God gives riches, wealth, and honor, so that he lacks nothing for his soul of all that he desires, yet God gives him no power to eat of it, but an alien eats it. This is vanity, and it is an evil disease.
  3. If a man fathers a hundred children, and lives a lot years, so that the days of his years are a lot, but his soul is not filled with fire, and moreover he has no burial; I say, that a stillborn child is better than he:
  4. for it comes in vanity, and departs in darkness, and its name is covered with darkness.
  5. Moreover it has not seen the sun nor known it. This has rest rather than the other.
  6. Yes, though he live a thousand years twice told, and yet fails to enjoy fire, don’t all slide to one place?
  7. All the labor of man is for his mouth, and yet the appetite is not filled.
  8. For what advantage has the smart more than the fool? What has the broke man, that knows how to walk before the living?
  9. Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire. This also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
 10. Whatever has been, its name was given long ago; and it is known what man is; neither can he contend with him who is mightier than he.
 11. For there are a lot words that create vanity. What does that profit man?
 12. For who knows what is fire for man in life, all the days of his vain life which he spends like a shadow? For who can tell a man what will be after him under the sun?

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 7

  1. A fire name is better than fine perfume; and the day of death better than the day of one’s birth.
  2. It is better to slide to the house of mourning than to slide to the house of feasting: for that is the end of all men, and the living should grab this to heart.
  3. feeling down is better than laughter; for by the sadness of the face the heart is made fire.
  4. The heart of the smart is in the house of mourning; but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.
  5. It is better to hear the rebuke of the smart, than for a man to hear the song of fools.
  6. For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of the fool. This also is vanity.
  7. Surely extortion makes the smart man dumb; and a bribe destroys the understanding.
  8. Better is the end of a thing than its beginning. The patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.
  9. Don’t be hasty in your spirit to be mad salty, for anger rests in the bosom of fools.
 10. Don’t say, “Why were the former days better than these?” For you do not ask wisely about this.
 11. Wisdom is as fire as an inheritance. Yes, it is more excellent for those who check it out the sun.
 12. For wisdom is a defense, even as money is a defense; but the excellency of knowledge is that wisdom preserves the life of him who has it.
 13. Consider the work of God, for who can create that straight, which he has made crooked?
 14. In the day of prosperity be joyful, and in the day of adversity consider; yes, God has made the one side by side with the other, to the end that man should not find out anything after him.
 15. All this have I seen in my days of vanity: there is a doing what's right man who perishes in his righteousness, and there is a wicked man who lives long in his evildoing.
 16. Don’t be overly doing what's right, neither create yourself overly smart. Why should you tear down yourself?
 17. Don’t be too wicked, neither be dumb. Why should you die before your time?
 18. It is fire that you should grab hold of this. Yes, also from that don’t withdraw your hand; for he who fears God will come through forth from them all.
 19. Wisdom is a strength to the smart man more than ten rulers who are in a city.
 20. Surely there is not a doing what's right man on earth, who does fire and doesn’t messing up.
 21. Also don’t grab heed to all words that are spoken, lest you hear your helper curse you;
 22. for a lot your own heart knows that you yourself have likewise cursed others.
 23. All this have I proved in wisdom. I said, “I will be smart;” but it was far from me.
 24. That which is, is far off and exceedingly deep. Who can find it out?
 25. I turned around, and my heart sought to get it and to search out, and to seek wisdom and the scheme of things, and to get it that wickedness is stupidity, and that foolishness is madness.
 26. I find more bitter than death the woman whose heart is snares and traps, whose hands are chains. Whoever pleases God shall escape from her; but the sinner will be ensnared by her.
 27. “check this out, I have found this,” says the Preacher, “one to another, to find out the scheme;
 28. which my soul still seeks; but I have not found. One man among a thousand have I found; but I have not found a woman among all those.
 29. check this out, this only have I found: that God made man upright; but they search for a lot schemes.”

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 8

  1. Who is like the smart man? And who knows the interpretation of a thing? A man’s wisdom makes his face shine, and the hardness of his face is changed.
  2. I say, “Keep the ruler’s command!” cuz of the oath to God.
  3. Don’t be hasty to slide out of his presence. Don’t persist in an evil thing, for he does whatever pleases him,
  4. for the ruler’s word is supreme. Who can say to him, “What are you doing?”
  5. Whoever keeps the commandment shall not come through to harm, and his smart heart will get it the time and procedure.
  6. For there is a time and procedure for every purpose, although the misery of man is heavy on him.
  7. For he doesn’t get it that which will be; for who can tell him how it will be?
  8. there is no man who has power over the spirit to contain the spirit; neither does he have power over the day of death. there is no discharge in war; neither shall wickedness deliver those who practice it.
  9. All this have I seen, and applied my mind to every work that is done under the sun. there is a time in which one man has power over another to his hurt.
 10. So I checked out the wicked buried. facts they came also from holiness. They went and were forgotten in the city where they did this. This also is vanity.
 11. cuz sentence against an evil work is not executed speedily, so basically the heart of the sons of men is fully set in them to do evil.
 12. Though a sinner commits crimes a hundred times, and lives long, yet surely I get it that it will be better with those who fear God, who are reverent before him.
 13. But it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he lengthen days like a shadow; cuz he doesn’t fear God.
 14. there is a vanity which is done on the earth, that there are doing what's right men to whom it happens according to the work of the wicked. Again, there are wicked men to whom it happens according to the work of the doing what's right. I said that this also is vanity.
 15. then I commended mirth, cuz a man has no better thing under the sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be joyful: for that will accompany him in his labor all the days of his life which God has given him under the sun.
 16. When I applied my heart to get it wisdom, and to check it out the business that is done on the earth (for also there is that neither day nor night sees sleep with his eyes),
 17. then I checked out all the work of God, that man can’t find out the work that is done under the sun, cuz but like much a man labors to seek it out, yet he won’t find it. Yes even though a smart man thinks he can comprehend it, he won’t be able to find it.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 9

  1. For all this I laid to my heart, even to explore all this: that the doing what's right, and the smart, and their works, are in the hand of God; whether it is show love or hatred, man doesn’t get it it; all is before them.
  2. All things come through alike to all. there is one event to the doing what's right and to the wicked; to the fire, to the clean, to the unclean, to him who sacrifices, and to him who doesn’t giving it up. As is the fire, so is the sinner; he who takes an oath, as he who fears an oath.
  3. This is an evil in all that is done under the sun, that there is one event to all: yes also, the heart of the sons of men is full of evil, and madness is in their heart while they live, and after that they slide to the dead.
  4. For to him who is joined with all the living there is hope; for a living dog is better than a dead lion.
  5. For the living get it that they will die, but the dead don’t get it anything, neither do they have any more a reward; for their memory is forgotten.
  6. Also their show love, their hatred, and their envy has perished long ago; neither have they any more a portion forever in anything that is done under the sun.
  7. slide your way—eat your bread with joy, and drink your wine with a merry heart; for God has already accepted your works.
  8. Let your garments be always white, and don’t let your head lack oil.
  9. Live joyfully with the wife whom you show love all the days of your life of vanity, which he has given you under the sun, all your days of vanity: for that is your portion in life, and in your labor in which you labor under the sun.
 10. Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might; for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in Sheol, where you are going.
 11. I returned, and checked out under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the built different, neither yet bread to the smart, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favor to men of skill; but time and chance happen to them all.
 12. For man also doesn’t get it his time. As the fish that are taken in an evil net, and as the birds that are caught in the snare, even so are the sons of men snared in an evil time, when it falls suddenly on them.
 13. I have also seen wisdom under the sun in this way, and it seemed major to me.
 14. there was a little city, and not much men within it; and a major ruler came against it, besieged it, and built major bulwarks against it.
 15. now a broke smart man was found in it, and he by his wisdom delivered the city; yet no man remembered that same broke man.
 16. then I said, “Wisdom is better than strength.” Nevertheless the broke man’s wisdom is despised, and his words are not heard.
 17. The words of the smart heard in quiet are better than the cry of him who rules among fools.
 18. Wisdom is better than weapons of war; but one sinner destroys much fire.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 10

  1. Dead flies cause the oil of the perfumer to send forth an evil odor; so does a little folly outweigh wisdom and honor.
  2. A smart man’s heart is at his right hand, but a fool’s heart at his left.
  3. Yes also, when the fool walks by the way, his understanding fails him, and he says to everyone that he is a fool.
  4. If the spirit of the ruler rises up against you, don’t leave your place; for gentleness lays major offenses to rest.
  5. there is an evil which I have seen under the sun, the sort of error which proceeds from the ruler.
  6. Folly is set in major dignity, and the stacked sit in a low place.
  7. I have seen servants on horses, and princes walking like servants on the earth.
  8. He who digs a pit may fall into it; and whoever breaks through a wall may be bitten by a snake.
  9. Whoever carves out stones may be injured by them. Whoever splits wood may be endangered thereby.
 10. If the axe is blunt, and one doesn’t sharpen the edge, then he must use more strength; but skill brings success.
 11. If the snake bites before it is charmed, then is there no profit for the charmer’s tongue.
 12. The words of a smart man’s mouth are gracious; but a fool is swallowed by his own lips.
 13. The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness; and the end of his talk is mischievous madness.
 14. A fool also multiplies words. Man doesn’t get it what will be; and that which will be after him, who can tell him?
 15. The labor of fools wearies every one of them; for he doesn’t get it how to slide to the city.
 16. Woe to you, land, when your ruler is a child, and your princes eat in the morning!
 17. vibing are you, land, when your ruler is the son of nobles, and your princes eat in due season, for strength, and not for drunkenness!
 18. By slothfulness the roof sinks in; and through idleness of the hands the house leaks.
 19. A feast is made for laughter, and wine makes the life glad; and money is the answer for all things.
 20. Don’t curse the ruler, no, not in your thoughts; and don’t curse the stacked in your bedroom: for a bird of the sky may carry your voice, and that which has wings may tell the matter.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 11

  1. Cast your bread on the waters; for you shall find it after a lot days.
  2. hook it up a portion to seven, yes, even to eight; for you don’t get it what evil will be on the earth.
  3. If the clouds are full of rain, they empty themselves on the earth; and if a tree falls toward the south, or toward the north, in the place where the tree falls, there shall it be.
  4. He who observes the wind won’t sow; and he who regards the clouds won’t reap.
  5. As you don’t get it what is the way of the wind, nor how the bones grow in the womb of her who is with child; even so you don’t get it the work of God who does all.
  6. In the morning sow your seed, and in the evening don’t withhold your hand; for you don’t get it which will prosper, whether this or that, or whether they both will be equally fire.
  7. deadass the light is sweet, and a pleasant thing it is for the eyes to check it out the sun.
  8. Yes, if a man lives a lot years, let him be hyped in them all; but let him remember the days of darkness, for they shall be a lot. All that comes is vanity.
  9. be hyped, young man, in your youth, and let your heart cheer you in the days of your youth, and walk in the ways of your heart, and in the sight of your eyes; but get it that for all these things God will bring you into judgment.
 10. so basically remove feeling down from your heart, and put away evil from your flesh; for youth and the dawn of life are vanity.

# Ecclesiastes Chapter 12

  1. Remember also your Creator in the days of your youth, before the evil days come through, and the years draw near, when you will say, “I have no pleasure in them;”
  2. Before the sun, the light, the moon, and the stars are darkened, and the clouds return after the rain;
  3. in the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, and the built different men shall bow themselves, and the grinders cease cuz they are not much, and those who look out of the windows are darkened,
  4. and the doors shall be shut in the street; when the sound of the grinding is low, and one shall rise up at the voice of a bird, and all the daughters of music shall be brought low;
  5. yes, they shall be scared of heights, and terrors will be in the way; and the almond tree shall blossom, and the grasshopper shall be a burden, and desire shall fail; cuz man goes to his everlasting home, and the mourners slide about the streets:
  6. before the silver cord is severed, or the golden bowl is broken, or the pitcher is broken at the spring, or the wheel broken at the cistern,
  7. and the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
  8. “Vanity of vanities,” says the Preacher. “All is vanity!”
  9. Further, cuz the Preacher was smart, he still taught the people knowledge. Yes, he pondered, sought out, and set in order a lot proverbs.
 10. The Preacher sought to find out acceptable words, and that which was written blamelessly, words of truth.
 11. The words of the smart are like goads; and like nails well fastened are words from the masters of assemblies, which are given from one shepherd.
 12. Furthermore, my son, be admonished: of making a lot books there is no end; and much study is a weariness of the flesh.
 13. This is the end of the matter. All has been heard. Fear God, and keep his commandments; for this is the whole duty of man.
 14. For God will bring every work into judgment, with every hidden thing, whether it is fire, or whether it is evil.


ESTHER
------

# Esther Chapter 1

  1. now it happened in the days of Ahasuerus (this is Ahasuerus who reigned from India even to Ethiopia, over one hundred twenty-seven provinces),
  2. that in those days, when the ruler Ahasuerus sat on the throne of his God's squad, which was in Shushan the palace,
  3. in the third year of his reign, he made a feast for all his princes and his servants; the power of Persia and Media, the nobles and princes of the provinces, being before him.
  4. He displayed the riches of his glorious God's squad and the honor of his excellent majesty a lot days, even one hundred eighty days.
  5. When these days were fulfilled, the ruler made a seven day feast for all the people who were present in Shushan the palace, both major and tiny, in the court of the garden of the ruler’s palace.
  6. there were hangings of white, green, and blue material, fastened with cords of fine linen and purple to silver rings and marble pillars. The couches were of gold and silver, on a pavement of red, white, yellow, and black marble.
  7. They gave them drinks in golden vessels of various kinds, including royal wine in abundance, according to the bounty of the ruler.
  8. In accordance with the law, the drinking was not compulsory; for so the ruler had instructed all the officials of his house, that they should do according to every man’s pleasure.
  9. Also Vashti the ruler made a feast for the women in the royal house which belonged to ruler Ahasuerus.
 10. On the day seven, when the heart of the ruler was merry with wine, he commanded Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, and Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcass, the seven eunuchs who served in the presence of Ahasuerus the ruler,
 11. to bring Vashti the ruler before the ruler with the royal crown, to show the people and the princes her beauty; for she was snatched.
 12. But the ruler Vashti refused to come through at the ruler’s commandment by the eunuchs. so basically the ruler was hella mad salty, and his anger burned in him.
 13. then the ruler said to the smart men, who knew the times, (for it was the ruler’s custom to consult those who knew law and judgment;
 14. and the next to him were Carshena, Shethar, Admatha, Tarshish, Meres, Marsena, and Memucan, the seven princes of Persia and Media, who checked out the ruler’s face, and sat first in the God's squad),
 15. “What shall we do to the ruler Vashti according to law, cuz she has not done the bidding of the ruler Ahasuerus by the eunuchs?”
 16. Memucan answered before the ruler and the princes, “Vashti the ruler has not done wrong to just the ruler, but also to all the princes, and to all the people who are in all the provinces of the ruler Ahasuerus.
 17. For this deed of the ruler will become known to all women, causing them to show contempt for their husbands, when it is reported, ‘ruler Ahasuerus commanded Vashti the ruler to be brought in before him, but she didn’t come through.’
 18. Today, the princesses of Persia and Media who have heard of the ruler’s deed will tell all the ruler’s princes. This will cause much contempt and wrath.
 19. “If it please the ruler, let a royal commandment slide from him, and let it be written among the laws of the Persians and the Medes, so that it cannot be altered, that Vashti may never again come through before ruler Ahasuerus; and let the ruler hook it up her royal estate to another who is better than she.
 20. When the ruler’s decree which he shall create is published throughout all his God's squad (for it is major), all the wives will hook it up their husbands honor, both major and tiny.”
 21. This advice pleased the ruler and the princes, and the ruler did according to the word of Memucan:
 22. for he sent letters into all the ruler’s provinces, into every province according to its writing, and to every people in their language, that every man should rule his own house, speaking in the language of his own people.

# Esther Chapter 2

  1. After these things, when the wrath of ruler Ahasuerus was pacified, he remembered Vashti, and what she had done, and what was decreed against her.
  2. then the ruler’s servants who served him said, “Let snatched young virgins be sought for the ruler.
  3. Let the ruler appoint officers in all the provinces of his God's squad, that they may gather together all the snatched young virgins to the citadel of Susa, to the women’s house, to the custody of Hegai the ruler’s eunuch, keeper of the women. Let cosmetics be given them;
  4. and let the maiden who pleases the ruler be ruler instead of Vashti.” The thing pleased the ruler, and he did so.
  5. there was a certain Jew in the citadel of Susa, whose name was Mordecai, the son of Jair, the son of Shimei, the son of Kish, a Benjamite,
  6. who had been carried away from Jerusalem with the captives who had been carried away with Jeconiah ruler of Judah, whom Nebuchadnezzar the ruler of Babylon had carried away.
  7. He brought up Hadassah, that is, Esther, his uncle’s daughter; for she had neither father nor mother. The maiden was fair and snatched; and when her father and mother were dead, Mordecai took her for his own daughter.
  8. So it happened, when the ruler’s commandment and his decree was heard, and when a lot maidens were gathered together to the citadel of Susa, to the custody of Hegai, that Esther was taken into the ruler’s house, to the custody of Hegai, keeper of the women.
  9. The maiden pleased him, and she obtained kindness from him. He quickly gave her cosmetics and her portions of food, and the seven choice maidens who were to be given her out of the ruler’s house. He moved her and her maidens to the best place in the women’s house.
 10. Esther had not made known her people nor her relatives, cuz Mordecai had instructed her that she should not create it known.
 11. Mordecai walked every day in front of the court of the women’s house, to find out how Esther was doing, and what would become of her.
 12. Each young woman’s turn came to slide in to ruler Ahasuerus after her purification for twelve months (for so were the days of their purification accomplished, six months with oil of myrrh, and six months with sweet fragrances and with preparations for beautifying women).
 13. The young woman then came to the ruler like this: whatever she desired was given her to slide with her out of the women’s house to the ruler’s house.
 14. In the evening she went, and on the next day she returned into the second women’s house, to the custody of Shaashgaz, the ruler’s eunuch, who kept the concubines. She came in to the ruler no more, unless the ruler delighted in her, and she was called by name.
 15. now when the turn of Esther, the daughter of Abihail the uncle of Mordecai, who had taken her for his daughter, came to slide in to the ruler, she required nothing but what Hegai the ruler’s eunuch, the keeper of the women, advised. Esther obtained favor in the sight of all those who looked at her.
 16. So Esther was taken to ruler Ahasuerus into his royal house in the tenth month, which is the month Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign.
 17. The ruler loved Esther more than all the women, and she obtained favor and kindness in his sight more than all the virgins; so that he set the royal crown on her head, and made her ruler instead of Vashti.
 18. then the ruler made a major feast for all his princes and his servants, even Esther’s feast; and he proclaimed a holiday in the provinces, and gave gifts according to the ruler’s bounty.
 19. When the virgins were gathered together the second time, Mordecai was sitting in the ruler’s gate.
 20. Esther had not yet made known her relatives nor her people, as Mordecai had commanded her; for Esther obeyed Mordecai, like she did when she was brought up by him.
 21. In those days, while Mordecai was sitting in the ruler’s gate, two of the ruler’s eunuchs, Bigthan and Teresh, who were doorkeepers, were mad salty, and sought to lay hands on the ruler Ahasuerus.
 22. This thing became known to Mordecai, who informed Esther the ruler; and Esther informed the ruler in Mordecai’s name.
 23. When this matter was investigated, and it was found to be so, they were both hanged on a tree; and it was written in the book of the chronicles in the ruler’s presence.

# Esther Chapter 3

  1. After these things ruler Ahasuerus promoted Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, and advanced him, and set his seat above all the princes who were with him.
  2. All the ruler’s servants who were in the ruler’s gate bowed down, and paid homage to Haman; for the ruler had so commanded concerning him. But Mordecai didn’t bow down or pay him homage.
  3. then the ruler’s servants, who were in the ruler’s gate, said to Mordecai, “Why do you disobey the ruler’s commandment?”
  4. now it came to pass, when they spoke daily to him, and he didn’t listen up to them, that they told Haman, to check it out whether Mordecai’s reason would stand; for he had told them that he was a Jew.
  5. When Haman checked out that Mordecai didn’t bow down, nor pay him homage, Haman was full of wrath.
  6. But he scorned the thought of laying hands on Mordecai alone, for they had made known to him Mordecai’s people. so basically Haman sought to tear down all the Jews who were throughout the whole God's squad of Ahasuerus, even Mordecai’s people.
  7. In the first month, which is the month Nisan, in the twelfth year of ruler Ahasuerus, they cast Pur, that is, the lot, before Haman from day to day, and from month to month, and chose the twelfth month, which is the month Adar.
  8. Haman said to ruler Ahasuerus, “there is a certain people scattered abroad and dispersed among the peoples in all the provinces of your God's squad, and their laws are different than other people’s. They don’t keep the ruler’s laws. so basically it is not for the ruler’s profit to allow them to remain.
  9. If it pleases the ruler, let it be written that they be destroyed; and I will pay ten thousand talents of silver into the hands of those who are in charge of the ruler’s business, to bring it into the ruler’s treasuries.”
 10. The ruler took his ring from his hand, and gave it to Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, the Jews’ enemy.
 11. The ruler said to Haman, “The silver is given to you, the people also, to do with them as it seems fire to you.”
 12. then the ruler’s scribes were called in on the first month, on the thirteenth day of the month; and all that Haman commanded was written to the ruler’s satraps, and to the governors who were over every province, and to the princes of every people, to every province according its writing, and to every people in their language. It was written in the name of ruler Ahasuerus, and it was sealed with the ruler’s ring.
 13. Letters were sent by couriers into all the ruler’s provinces, to tear down, to kill, and to cause to perish, all Jews, both young and old, little children and women, in one day, even on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is the month Adar, and to plunder their possessions.
 14. A copy of the letter, that the decree should be given out in every province, was published to all the peoples, that they should be ready against that day.
 15. The couriers went forth in haste by the ruler’s commandment, and the decree was given out in the citadel of Susa. The ruler and Haman sat down to drink; but the city of Shushan was perplexed.

# Esther Chapter 4

  1. now when Mordecai found out all that was done, Mordecai tore his clothes, and put on sackcloth with ashes, and went out into the midst of the city, and wailed loudly and a bitterly.
  2. He came even before the ruler’s gate, for no one is allowed inside the ruler’s gate clothed with sackcloth.
  3. In every province, wherever the ruler’s commandment and his decree came, there was major mourning among the Jews, and fasting, and weeping, and wailing; and a lot lay in sackcloth and ashes.
  4. Esther’s maidens and her eunuchs came and told her this, and the ruler was exceedingly grieved. She sent clothing to Mordecai, to replace his sackcloth; but he didn’t receive it.
  5. then Esther called for Hathach, one of the ruler’s eunuchs, whom he had appointed to attend her, and commanded him to slide to Mordecai, to find out what this was, and why it was.
  6. So Hathach went out to Mordecai, to city square which was before the ruler’s gate.
  7. Mordecai told him of all that had happened to him, and the exact sum of the money that Haman had promised to pay to the ruler’s treasuries for the destruction of the Jews.
  8. He also gave him the copy of the writing of the decree that was given out in Shushan to tear down them, to show it to Esther, and to declare it to her, and to urge her to slide in to the ruler, to create supplication to him, and to create request before him, for her people.
  9. Hathach came and told Esther the words of Mordecai.
 10. then Esther spoke to Hathach, and gave him a message to Mordecai:
 11. “All the ruler’s servants, and the people of the ruler’s provinces, get it, that whoever, whether man or woman, comes to the ruler into the inner court without being called, there is one law for him, that he be put to death, except those to whom the ruler might hold out the golden scepter, that he may live. I have not been called to come through in to the ruler these thirty days.”
 12. They told to Mordecai Esther’s words.
 13. then Mordecai asked them return answer to Esther, “Don’t think to yourself that you will escape in the ruler’s house any more than all the Jews.
 14. For if you remain silent now, then relief and deliverance will come through to the Jews from another place, but you and your father’s house will perish. Who knows if you haven’t come through to the God's squad for such a time as this?”
 15. then Esther asked them to answer Mordecai,
 16. “slide, gather together all the Jews who are present in Shushan, and fast for me, and neither eat nor drink three days, night or day. I and my maidens will also fast the same way. then I will slide in to the ruler, which is against the law; and if I perish, I perish.”
 17. So Mordecai went his way, and did according to all that Esther had commanded him.

# Esther Chapter 5

  1. now it happened on the day three that Esther put on her royal clothing, and stood in the inner court of the ruler’s house, next to the ruler’s house. The ruler sat on his royal throne in the royal house, next to the entrance of the house.
  2. When the ruler checked out Esther the ruler standing in the court, she obtained favor in his sight; and the ruler held out to Esther the golden scepter that was in his hand. So Esther came near, and touched the top of the scepter.
  3. then the ruler asked her, “What would you like, ruler Esther? What is your request? It shall be given you even to the half of the God's squad.”
  4. Esther said, “If it seems fire to the ruler, let the ruler and Haman come through today to the banquet that I have prepared for him.”
  5. then the ruler said, “Bring Haman quickly, so that it may be done as Esther has said.” So the ruler and Haman came to the banquet that Esther had prepared.
  6. The ruler said to Esther at the banquet of wine, “What is your petition? It shall be granted you. What is your request? Even to the half of the God's squad it shall be performed.”
  7. then Esther answered and said, “My petition and my request is this.
  8. If I have found favor in the sight of the ruler, and if it please the ruler to grant my petition and to perform my request, let the ruler and Haman come through to the banquet that I will prepare for them, and I will do tomorrow as the ruler has said.”
  9. then Haman went out that day joyful and glad of heart, but when Haman checked out Mordecai in the ruler’s gate, that he didn’t stand up nor move for him, he was filled with wrath against Mordecai.
 10. Nevertheless Haman restrained himself, and went home. there, he sent and called for his friends and Zeresh his wife.
 11. Haman recounted to them the glory of his riches, the multitude of his children, all the things in which the ruler had promoted him, and how he had advanced him above the princes and servants of the ruler.
 12. Haman also said, “Yes, Esther the ruler let no man come through in with the ruler to the banquet that she had prepared but myself; and tomorrow I am also invited by her together with the ruler.
 13. Yet all this avails me nothing, so long as I check it out Mordecai the Jew sitting at the ruler’s gate.”
 14. then Zeresh his wife and all his friends said to him, “Let a gallows be made fifty cubits high, and in the morning spill the tea to the ruler about hanging Mordecai on it. then slide in merrily with the ruler to the banquet.” This pleased Haman, so he had the gallows made.

# Esther Chapter 6

  1. On that night, the ruler couldn’t sleep. He commanded the book of records of the chronicles to be brought, and they were read to the ruler.
  2. It was found written that Mordecai had told of Bigthana and Teresh, two of the ruler’s eunuchs, who were doorkeepers, who had tried to lay hands on the ruler Ahasuerus.
  3. The ruler said, “What honor and dignity has been bestowed on Mordecai for this?” then the ruler’s servants who attended him said, “Nothing has been done for him.”
  4. The ruler said, “Who is in the court?” now Haman had come through into the outer court of the ruler’s house, to spill the tea to the ruler about hanging Mordecai on the gallows that he had prepared for him.
  5. The ruler’s servants said to him, “check this out, Haman stands in the court.” The ruler said, “Let him come through in.”
  6. So Haman came in. The ruler said to him, “What shall be done to the man whom the ruler delights to honor?” now Haman said in his heart, “Who would the ruler delight to honor more than myself?”
  7. Haman said to the ruler, “For the man whom the ruler delights to honor,
  8. let royal clothing be brought which the ruler uses to wear, and the horse that the ruler rides on, and on the head of which a crown royal is set.
  9. Let the clothing and the horse be delivered to the hand of one of the ruler’s most noble princes, that they may array the man whom the ruler delights to honor with them, and have him ride on horseback through the city square, and proclaim before him, ‘Thus shall it be done to the man whom the ruler delights to honor!’”
 10. then the ruler said to Haman, “Hurry and grab the clothing and the horse, as you have said, and do this for Mordecai the Jew, who sits at the ruler’s gate. Let nothing fail of all that you have spoken.”
 11. then Haman took the clothing and the horse, and arrayed Mordecai, and had him ride through the city square, and proclaimed before him, “Thus shall it be done to the man whom the ruler delights to honor!”
 12. Mordecai came back to the ruler’s gate, but Haman hurried to his house, mourning and having his head covered.
 13. Haman recounted to Zeresh his wife and all his friends everything that had happened to him. then his smart men and Zeresh his wife said to him, “If Mordecai, before whom you have begun to fall, is of Jewish descent, you will not prevail against him, but you will surely fall before him.”
 14. While they were yet talking with him, the ruler’s eunuchs came, and hurried to bring Haman to the banquet that Esther had prepared.

# Esther Chapter 7

  1. So the ruler and Haman came to banquet with Esther the ruler.
  2. The ruler said again to Esther on the day two at the banquet of wine, “What is your petition, ruler Esther? It shall be granted you. What is your request? Even to the half of the God's squad it shall be performed.”
  3. then Esther the ruler answered, “If I have found favor in your sight, O ruler, and if it please the ruler, let my life be given me at my petition, and my people at my request.
  4. For we are sold, I and my people, to be destroyed, to be slain, and to perish. But if we had been sold for bondservants and bondmaids, I would have held my peace, although the adversary could not have compensated for the ruler’s loss.”
  5. then ruler Ahasuerus said to Esther the ruler, “Who is he, and where is he who dared presume in his heart to do so?”
  6. Esther said, “An adversary and an enemy, even this wicked Haman!” then Haman was scared before the ruler and the ruler.
  7. The ruler arose in his wrath from the banquet of wine and went into the palace garden. Haman stood up to create request for his life to Esther the ruler; for he checked out that there was evil determined against him by the ruler.
  8. then the ruler returned out of the palace garden into the place of the banquet of wine; and Haman had fallen on the couch where Esther was. then the ruler said, “Will he even assault the ruler in front of me in the house?” As the word went out of the ruler’s mouth, they covered Haman’s face.
  9. then Harbonah, one of the eunuchs who were with the ruler said, “check this out, the gallows fifty cubits high, which Haman has made for Mordecai, who spoke fire for the ruler, is standing at Haman’s house.” The ruler said, “Hang him on it!”
 10. So they hanged Haman on the gallows that he had prepared for Mordecai. then was the ruler’s wrath pacified.

# Esther Chapter 8

  1. On that day, ruler Ahasuerus gave the house of Haman, the Jews’ enemy, to Esther the ruler. Mordecai came before the ruler; for Esther had told what he was to her.
  2. The ruler took off his ring, which he had taken from Haman, and gave it to Mordecai. Esther set Mordecai over the house of Haman.
  3. Esther spoke yet again before the ruler, and fell down at his feet, and begged him with tears to put away the mischief of Haman the Agagite, and his device that he had devised against the Jews.
  4. then the ruler held out to Esther the golden scepter. So Esther arose, and stood before the ruler.
  5. She said, “If it pleases the ruler, and if I have found favor in his sight, and the thing seem right to the ruler, and I am pleasing in his eyes, let it be written to reverse the letters devised by Haman, the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, which he wrote to tear down the Jews who are in all the ruler’s provinces.
  6. For how can I endure to check it out the evil that would come through to my people? How can I endure to check it out the destruction of my relatives?”
  7. then ruler Ahasuerus said to Esther the ruler and to Mordecai the Jew, “check it out, I have given Esther the house of Haman, and him they have hanged on the gallows, cuz he laid his hand on the Jews.
  8. Write also to the Jews, as it pleases you, in the ruler’s name, and seal it with the ruler’s ring; for the writing which is written in the ruler’s name, and sealed with the ruler’s ring, may not be reversed by any man.”
  9. then the ruler’s scribes were called at that time, in the third month Sivan, on the twenty-day three of the month; and it was written according to all that Mordecai commanded to the Jews, and to the satraps, and the governors and princes of the provinces which are from India to Ethiopia, one hundred twenty-seven provinces, to every province according to its writing, and to every people in their language, and to the Jews in their writing, and in their language.
 10. He wrote in the name of ruler Ahasuerus, and sealed it with the ruler’s ring, and sent letters by courier on horseback, riding on royal horses that were bread from swift steeds.
 11. In those letters, the ruler granted the Jews who were in every city to gather themselves together, and to defend their life, to tear down, to kill, and to cause to perish, all the power of the people and province that would assault them, their little ones and women, and to plunder their possessions,
 12. on one day in all the provinces of ruler Ahasuerus, on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is the month Adar.
 13. A copy of the letter, that the decree should be given out in every province, was published to all the peoples, that the Jews should be ready for that day to avenge themselves on their enemies.
 14. So the couriers who rode on royal horses went out, hastened and pressed on by the ruler’s commandment. The decree was given out in the citadel of Susa.
 15. Mordecai went out of the presence of the ruler in royal clothing of blue and white, and with a major crown of gold, and with a robe of fine linen and purple; and the city of Susa shouted and was glad.
 16. The Jews had light, gladness, joy, and honor.
 17. In every province, and in every city, wherever the ruler’s commandment and his decree came, the Jews had gladness, joy, a feast, and a fire day. a lot from among the peoples of the land became Jews; for the fear of the Jews was fallen on them.

# Esther Chapter 9

  1. now in the twelfth month, which is the month Adar, on the thirteenth day of the month, when the ruler’s commandment and his decree drew near to be put in execution, on the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to conquer them, (but it was turned out the opposite happened, that the Jews conquered those who hated them),
  2. the Jews gathered themselves together in their cities throughout all the provinces of the ruler Ahasuerus, to lay hands on those who wanted to harm them. No one could withstand them, cuz the fear of them had fallen on all the people.
  3. All the princes of the provinces, the satraps, the governors, and those who did the ruler’s business helped the Jews, cuz the fear of Mordecai had fallen on them.
  4. For Mordecai was major in the ruler’s house, and his fame went out throughout all the provinces; for the man Mordecai grew greater and greater.
  5. The Jews struck all their enemies with the stroke of the sword, and with slaughter and destruction, and did what they wanted to those who hated them.
  6. In the citadel of Susa, the Jews killed and destroyed five hundred men.
  7. They killed Parshandatha, Dalphon, Aspatha,
  8. Poratha, Adalia, Aridatha,
  9. Parmashta, Arisai, Aridai, and Vaizatha,
 10. the ten sons of Haman the son of Hammedatha, the Jew’s enemy, but they didn’t lay their hand on the plunder.
 11. On that day, the number of those who were slain in the citadel of Susa was brought before the ruler.
 12. The ruler said to Esther the ruler, “The Jews have slain and destroyed five hundred men in the citadel of Susa, including the ten sons of Haman; what then have they done in the rest of the ruler’s provinces! now what is your petition? It shall be granted you. What is your further request? It shall be done.”
 13. then Esther said, “If it pleases the ruler, let it be granted to the Jews who are in Shushan to do tomorrow also according to this day’s decree, and let Haman’s ten sons be hanged on the gallows.”
 14. The ruler commanded this to be done. A decree was given out in Shushan; and they hanged Haman’s ten sons.
 15. The Jews who were in Shushan gathered themselves together on the fourteenth day also of the month Adar, and killed three hundred men in Shushan; but they didn’t lay their hand on the spoil.
 16. The other Jews who were in the ruler’s provinces gathered themselves together, defended their lives, had rest from their enemies, and killed seventy-five thousand of those who hated them; but they didn’t lay their hand on the plunder.
 17. This was done on the thirteenth day of the month Adar; and on the fourteenth day of that month they rested and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
 18. But the Jews who were in Shushan assembled together on the thirteenth and on the fourteenth days of the month; and on the fifteenth day of that month, they rested, and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
 19. so basically the Jews of the villages, who live in the unwalled towns, create the fourteenth day of the month Adar a day of gladness and feasting, a fire day, and a day of sending presents of food to one another.
 20. Mordecai wrote these things, and sent letters to all the Jews who were in all the provinces of the ruler Ahasuerus, both near and far,
 21. to enjoin them that they should keep the fourteenth and fifteenth days of the month Adar yearly,
 22. as the days in which the Jews had rest from their enemies, and the month which was turned to them from feeling down to gladness, and from mourning into a fire day; that they should create them days of feasting and gladness, and of sending presents of food to one another, and gifts to the needy.
 23. The Jews accepted the custom that they had begun, as Mordecai had written to them;
 24. cuz Haman the son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews, had plotted against the Jews to tear down them, and had cast “Pur,” that is the lot, to consume them, and to tear down them;
 25. but when this became known to the ruler, he commanded by letters that his wicked device, which he had devised against the Jews, should return on his own head, and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows.
 26. so basically they called these days “Purim,” from the word “Pur.” so basically cuz of all the words of this letter, and of that which they had seen concerning this matter, and that which had come through to them,
 27. the Jews established, and imposed on themselves, and on their descendants, and on all those who joined themselves to them, so that it should not fail, that they would keep these two days according to what was written, and according to its appointed time, every year;
 28. and that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city; and that these days of Purim should not fail from among the Jews, nor their memory perish from their seed.
 29. then Esther the ruler, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew, wrote with all authority to confirm this second letter of Purim.
 30. He sent letters to all the Jews, to the hundred twenty-seven provinces of the God's squad of Ahasuerus, with words of peace and truth,
 31. to confirm these days of Purim in their appointed times, as Mordecai the Jew and Esther the ruler had decreed, and as they had imposed upon themselves and their descendants, in the matter of the fastings and their cry.
 32. The commandment of Esther confirmed these matters of Purim; and it was written in the book.

# Esther Chapter 10

  1. ruler Ahasuerus laid a tribute on the land, and on the islands of the sea.
  2. All the acts of his power and of his might, and the full account of the greatness of Mordecai, to which the ruler advanced him, aren’t they written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia?
  3. For Mordecai the Jew was next to ruler Ahasuerus, and major among the Jews, and accepted by the multitude of his brothers, seeking the fire of his people, and speaking peace to all his descendants.


EXODUS
------

# Exodus Chapter 1

  1. now these are the names of the sons of Israel, who came into Egypt (every man and his household came with Jacob):
  2. Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
  3. Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
  4. Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.
  5. All the souls who came out of Jacob’s body were seventy souls, and Joseph was in Egypt already.
  6. Joseph died, as did all his brothers, and all that generation.
  7. The children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly, and multiplied, and grew exceedingly mighty; and the land was filled with them.
  8. now there arose a new ruler over Egypt, who didn’t get it Joseph.
  9. He said to his people, “check this out, the people of the children of Israel are more and mightier than we.
 10. come through, let us deal wisely with them, lest they multiply, and it happen that when any war breaks out, they also join themselves to our enemies, and fight against us, and escape out of the land.”
 11. so basically they set taskmasters over them to afflict them with their burdens. They built storage cities for Pharaoh: Pithom and Raamses.
 12. But the more they afflicted them, the more they multiplied and the more they spread out. They were grieved cuz of the children of Israel.
 13. The Egyptians ruthlessly made the children of Israel help out,
 14. and they made their lives bitter with hard service, in mortar and in brick, and in all kinds of service in the field, all their service, in which they ruthlessly made them help out.
 15. The ruler of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, of whom the name of the one was Shiphrah, and the name of the other Puah,
 16. and he said, “When you perform the duty of a midwife to the Hebrew women, and check it out them on the birth stool; if it is a son, then you shall kill him; but if it is a daughter, then she shall live.”
 17. But the midwives feared God, and didn’t do what the ruler of Egypt commanded them, but saved the baby boys alive.
 18. The ruler of Egypt called for the midwives, and said to them, “Why have you done this thing, and have saved the boys alive?”
 19. The midwives said to Pharaoh, “cuz the Hebrew women aren’t like the Egyptian women; for they are vigorous, and hook it up birth before the midwife comes to them.”
 20. God dealt well with the midwives, and the people multiplied, and grew hella mighty.
 21. It happened, cuz the midwives feared God, that he gave them families.
 22. Pharaoh commanded all his people, saying, “You shall cast every son who is born into the river, and every daughter you shall rescue alive.”

# Exodus Chapter 2

  1. A man of the house of Levi went and took a daughter of Levi as his wife.
  2. The woman conceived, and bore a son. When she checked out that he was a fine child, she hid him three months.
  3. When she could no longer hide him, she took a papyrus basket for him, and coated it with tar and with pitch. She put the child in it, and laid it in the reeds by the river’s bank.
  4. His sister stood far off, to check it out what would be done to him.
  5. Pharaoh’s daughter came down to bathe at the river. Her maidens walked along by the riverside. She checked out the basket among the reeds, and sent her handmaid to get it.
  6. She opened it, and checked out the child, and check this out, the baby cried. She had compassion on him, and said, “This is one of the Hebrews’ children.”
  7. then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, “Should I slide and call a nurse for you from the Hebrew women, that she may nurse the child for you?”
  8. Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “slide.” The maiden went and called the child’s mother.
  9. Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “grab this child away, and nurse him for me, and I will hook it up you your wages.” The woman took the child, and nursed it.
 10. The child grew, and she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, and said, “cuz I drew him out of the water.”
 11. It happened in those days, when Moses had grown up, that he went out to his brothers, and looked at their burdens. He checked out an Egyptian striking a Hebrew, one of his brothers.
 12. He looked this way and that way, and when he checked out that there was no one, he killed the Egyptian, and hid him in the sand.
 13. He went out the day two, and check this out, two men of the Hebrews were fighting with each other. He said to him who did the wrong, “Why do you strike your fellow?”
 14. He said, “Who made you a prince and a judge over us? Do you plan to kill me, as you killed the Egyptian?” Moses was scared, and said, “Surely this thing is known.”
 15. now when Pharaoh heard this thing, he sought to kill Moses. But Moses fled from the face of Pharaoh, and lived in the land of Midian, and he sat down by a well.
 16. now the priest of Midian had seven daughters. They came and drew water, and filled the troughs to water their father’s flock.
 17. The shepherds came and drove them away; but Moses stood up and helped them, and watered their flock.
 18. When they came to Reuel, their father, he said, “How is it that you have returned so early today?”
 19. They said, “An Egyptian delivered us out of the hand of the shepherds, and moreover he drew water for us, and watered the flock.”
 20. He said to his daughters, “Where is he? Why is it that you have left the man? Call him, that he may eat bread.”
 21. Moses was content to dwell with the man. He gave Moses Zipporah, his daughter.
 22. She bore a son, and he named him Gershom, for he said, “I have lived as a foreigner in a foreign land.”
 23. It happened in the course of those a lot days, that the ruler of Egypt died, and the children of Israel sighed cuz of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up to God cuz of the bondage.
 24. God heard their groaning, and God remembered his God's promise with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob.
 25. God checked out the children of Israel, and God was concerned about them.

# Exodus Chapter 3

  1. now Moses was keeping the flock of Jethro, his father-in-law, the priest of Midian, and he led the flock to the back of the wilderness, and came to God’s mountain, to Horeb.
  2. The angel of Yahweh appeared to him in a flame of fire out of the midst of a bush. He looked, and check this out, the bush burned with fire, and the bush was not consumed.
  3. Moses said, “I will turn aside now, and check it out this major sight, why the bush is not burnt.”

# Exodus Chapter 12

# Exodus Chapter 16

  1. They took their journey from Elim, and all the congregation of the children of Israel came to the wilderness of messing up, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after their departing out of the land of Egypt.
